content: Please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button â‰¡, then select Help > More Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.
creator: christ1

content:
Was that a zipped profile? If so, I suggest you try unzipping it and the manually restoring it. Try these steps:

  1. unzip the profile
  2. exit thunderbird, if running
  3. enter %appdata% into the search box on task bar in windows and press enter
  4. this should take you to the appdata folder
  5. click the thunderbird folder and then the profiles folder
  6. paste your profile into the profiles folder - note the profile name as you will need it later
  7. start thunderbird and click help>troubleshootinginformation
  8. scroll down to "profiles' in left column and click 'about:profiles'
  9. click 'create profile' button in upper left
  10. click next
  11. enter shortname for profile, such as MYPROFILE and then click 'choose' button to locate and select your profile'
  12. click finish and launch the profile
creator: davidsk

content:
The most simple (and easiest) way is to use the TB built-in CardDAV support. You'd need to create a new CardDAV address book.

open a new Address Book tab in Thunderbird click the 'Create a new address book' icon at the top left corner of the Address Book tab choose 'Add CardDAV Address Book' provide you Gmail email address for 'Username', and leave the 'Location' field blank enter your Google account password when prompted, and give Thunderbird permissions to access your Google Address Book. Note, cookies need to be temporarily allowed in Thunderbird for this to work.

The new Google Address Book will show up in the left pane of the Address Book tab. You can rename the address book once it has been created.
creator: christ1
